children.subject: They have to book rooms that are the size of the class. If they didn't the office would effectively be endorsing students not showing up to lecture.
Dwinelle 145 isn't that big, I think 155 is the bigger one

8:00 AM lectures? Why does the registrar's office insist on booking the largest lecture halls for CS classes when only a small fraction of students actually attend live lecture on a regular basis? As a result, we now have a lecture scheduled in a large room that will be empty past the first week, given that live lecture attendance is already usually pretty low even when classes aren't at 8 in the morning.
At this time there are no plans to expand beyond 408 seats. That doesn't mean it won't happen, it just means there is no plan to expand it at this time.
Past student here: 162 has never grown past 400-ish students
Will 162 expand to a similar size to what it was in previous semesters?
Figured it out. Caused by opening "search for classes" in CalCentral under the wrong semester and  then switching to Fall 2019 in the class search screen.
Trying to enroll in the class is giving me an error: "The class number entered is a duplicate. Try another." Does anybody know what could be causing this issue?ld be causing this error?
Nvm, figured it out.
Is there no waitlist for 162?
Class is already full and there are many people on the waitlist so it doesn't seem like it
Do you think cs162 is safe to phase 2?
Same... I enrolled the day of and I'm very far down the waitlist. I need to take this class next semester. :/
Yeah same :(

You can count on SOME people to drop but the project-based, early drop classes don't follow the 10% rule as closely as other classes. 

I will advise THIS however - if you decide you do not want to be in this class, you should DROP from the wait list. Because this is an early-drop deadline class, it has happened in the past that students get into the class after the drop deadline when they had changed their mind. Problem was they added AFTER the drop deadline & then weren't able to drop the class without using the late change form that you're only able to use once in your academic career.
Does anyone know if the 10% rule for the waitlist still applies for 162 since most people are in groups? I’m pretty far down the waitlist but most of my group members were able to get in :(
If there is a better/more official place to voice my feedback I would be open to that as well.

I agree with OP. Rising senior over here, requiring 162 for research (and design requirement) and when I tried to enroll the class was already full, with a long waitlist. I don't know how good of a decision was to close the class. It really affected my priority to enroll in the course. While I understand that it came to mind closing the class as a good idea, I think that enrollment priorities should be enforced. Can the class and waitlist please be purged to support these priorities? It seems unfair to me that sophomore/junior students that saw this post earlier could sign up before, even when they are supposed to have a lower enrollment priority. This is also undermining students that have less time to complete the rest of their requirements. If the class cannot be purged, at least it should be expanded to account for rising seniors that could not enroll because of it being closed (and now full)
Hello, I totally agree. Is there any way you could expand enrollment?

I agree with it as well. I didn't expect that close to 200 seats could be filled up within a few hours of opening. It'll be very fair and reasonable to expand the class considering the short notice, rapid enrollment and high demand
I think one of the main bottlenecks is that 162 tends to do inclass midterms so they want to only fill up to room capacity
Strongly agree with above, I am a rising senior and now I am on waitlist 80+, opening the class late to all students totally makes the enrollment period meaningless.

FWIW, I don’t think the advisors who sometimes monitor this forum can do much about this. I completely agree with your concerns & would write to both the 162 Professor and the CS chair. 

(Of course... phrase it cordially and argue the case well.)
Just got an email saying the class would be expanded to accommodate seniors who are on the waitlist

How is it fair for a class to open up to the entire student body on one day and be filled immediately? Essentially what happened here is the Regents/DSP/Early Enrollment Students got in to the class, all regular registration seniors were closed off from the class, and now in one solid day, maybe even before a student could open Piazza to check, the entire class is full. What purpose does enrollment priority even serve in situations like this and why weren't we allowed to just enroll in the class and drop after if the new time did not meet our schedules? The class is webcast and with an 8AM slot, less than 10% of the class will probably attend live lecture so it wouldn't have even mattered. This feels unfair and also prevents seniors who have taken most other courses from actually being able to take the courses they need. 

Just my feedback and thoughts.

What makes you think it didn't take effect? It did - there are just that many majors.

You can see how the seats were reserved/filled here: https://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2019-fall-compsci-162-001-lec-001
I'm believe I'm lower on the waitlist than several underclassmen that are undeclared (anecdotal), so just wanted to make sure. If this is not the case, then I apologize for the misunderstanding.
I believe that you are added to the waitlist in order of when you signed up but they take into account priority when processing it

That is correct - you are added to the wait list in the order in which you attempt to enroll into the class. It's based on date and time you attempted enrollment to determine the wait list position.

HOWEVER, when the system automatically processes (which happens twice daily now and 4 times a day once the adjustment period begins) it prioritizes enrollment based on the reserve requirement groupsuntil that setting expires at the end of phase 2. (see the class in classes.berkeley.edu to view reserve seating groups)

For example: If you are an EECS or CS major who is in position 3 on the wait list and the students in positions 1 & 2 are NOT EECS or CS majors, you will be moved into the open seat ahead of the other students if/when a seat becomes available - assuming that happens before the end of phase 2.

On 8/19/19 the adjustment period begins and at that time the system will automatically enroll students into any open seats based solely on their wait list position.

Just noticed that 162 opened up about 50 more spots today in the class; however, I was originally around 50th on the waitlist and now still sit at 38th on the waitlist despite being an EECS major. Slightly confused why the above mentioned waitlist processing didn't kick in?
could be based on senior priority?

Similar situation as above. I find it impressive how in the past long strides have been taken to enforce enrollment rules for courses like 189 but how little is being done so that seniors can get in the class. I am still #42 in the waitlist
Am a rising EECS senior and am position 51 on the waitlist.
Why does priority enrollment for CS majors not take effect for this class?
Wait list is not closed for CS 162
why the waitlist is closed
You would have to contact teaching staff with this question. Only they know how far they want to go with making accommodations for alternate final times.
Will an alternate final be offered to students who have a time conflict even if the other class is not cs188 or cs70 due to the time change?

history.content:
The LECTURE for CS 162 has been MOVED and the DAY/TIME has changed! The lecture will now be held in Evans 10 on Tuesdays/Thursdays from 2:00 - 3:30pm.

The instructor has indicated that if necessary, he will offer alternate final for this class to avoid conflicts with finals for CS 188 or CS 70.

----------------------

Original note: Enroll into the Lecture and 999 section. Actual section assignments will be dealt with by teaching staff.

This class will be webcast.

Remember: This is an Early Drop Deadline class!
